text: Hi Chloe! I hope you had a lovely Christmas and happy new year~ Over the holidays, I had to go abroad to Pakistan to attend a wedding and visit relatives so thats kept me busy! Apologies again for the late update - I sometimes feel nervous about posting because I know theres still a lot to improve but I still need to try and get my work out there.

I have an update on the restaurant animation - I've been really on a off with this one. I realise there was a big learning curving with this as I'm animating two characters who are both using props and interacting with a little bit of lip sync. I've struggled with timing and my animation still seems a little stiff. I've mostly worked on frames 1-175 for the girl but still need to work on the waiter:

<https://syncsketch.com/sketch/644784102d2c/#1286352/1319905>

I tried to follow the workflow of this animator I'm following on youtube called Alessandro Camporota

<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1Y1EzmNT9BQ>

He's split his process into 4 parts which I found incredibly useful. However, after trying his method, I think it might not be for me as it takes me alot longer to animate and I struggle with timing when I start animating from stepped.

attachments.title: How To Animate (part1): Planning your shot (maya)
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: How To Animate (part1): Planning your shot (maya)

text:
I've also been working on a ballet dance piece. It also still needs a lot of work but I thought the sooner I get crit from this the better:

<https://syncsketch.com/sketch/e485a099ca0d/#1298535/1332093>

Regarding workflow, could I ask how you approach animating a shot? :open_mouth:
Do you also begin by blocking poses out in stepped before moving onto spline? Or do you block in spline from the beginning?

I've heard its different for animator and some animators prefer to just animate from spline for blocking - especially creature animators.
